title: How to find musicians to work for you - Quora

response.answer_text: Work FOR you? As in, you’re in charge? All the musical decisions are yours alone, and they’re the hired help brought in to do what you ask? Then you’d better be willing to pay them for their time and skills. If you’ve got a budget, then you can find musicians in lots of places. Call your local AFM (if you’re not in the US, call whatever union or guild represents musicians where you are) and tell them what instruments you’re looking forCall recording studios, producers, etc. and ask for namesNetwork with the musicians you knowPlace ads on Craislist or on musician websitesIf you have no money to offer, ask yourself why anyone would give up their time to be part of your project. Your talent pool will be far more limited, and you’ll have to offer them something they value in exchange for your time. Is your music interesting? Challenging? Can you offer the potential of income down the road? (And I’m talking concrete potential - do you have management? Gigs lined up? A substantial following? A network of contacts that will be of value to the people who ‘work for’ you?) If you don’t have any of the above, you need to rethink your premise. Because if you have nothing to trade in exchange for their work, you are NOT going to find musicians to work for you. You might find musicians who will work with you. If you’re willing to not be in charge, go to jam sessions, open mics, songwriter’s clubs. Approach buskers and ask if they’d like to jam sometime. But be realistic. Good musicians have invested a lot of time and effort in developing their skills. In order to get someone to play for free, you need to be the best offer on the table.

This is a great question! The simple answer is to work within your network. If you do not know anyone directly, asking friends and acquaintances for recommendations is a great way to find reliable musicians to work with.
